Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: LTREB: The role of ecological heterogeneity in a long-term grassland restoration experiment
Award.AbstractNarration: Many aspects of plant community structure and ecosystem functioning have been degraded by human disturbance to the environment, and may not return without human intervention through ecological restoration. Restoring biodiversity in disturbed ecosystems is a nearly-universal challenge, as well as an opportunity to test general ecological principles about species coexistence. This project will extend a 14-year test of whether heterogeneity in the environment creates vacancies and accessible resources that allow new species to establish and coexist in a community. Seeds of new species will be added to a prairie restoration experiment that was initiated in 1997. The experiment includes plots with up to four levels of soil heterogeneity, which has resulted in the development of plant communities that vary in the number and abundance of species among soil treatments and different years. The 14-year analysis of plant communities in this experiment demonstrated that plant diversity has declined over time, but more species have been maintained in plots with variable soil resources. If plots with greater ecological variability contain more resources for new species to exploit in space and time, then this study will demonstrate that the general ecological principle "heterogeneity begets diversity" can be applied to increase biodiversity in restored grasslands, where declining plant diversity over time is a common phenomenon. Further, this study will identify which plant traits contribute to successful establishment and persistence, which will inform species selection to maintain biodiversity over the long term. This project will also provide support for graduate education, offer hands-on training in restoration to undergraduates, and foster public education about prairie restoration as a demonstration site and resource for docent training, natural resource managers, high school teachers, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As human-driven environmental change continues to degrade ecosystems, there is escalating need to understand how to manage processes that maintain and promote biodiversity. Conversion of grasslands to agriculture reduces biodiversity, landscape heterogeneity, and availability of seeds from communities of native plant species for use in grassland regeneration. Because a large area of temperate grasslands, including the tallgrass prairie, has been converted to other uses, conservation of this biome is a high priority. Human intervention is needed to convert land in row-crop production back to tallgrass prairie. Although prairie restoration has been occurring for over a century, most reconstructed prairies exhibit declining plant diversity over time. This is often attributed to increasing dominance of grasses and limited variability in resources available for use by other species that contribute most to community diversity. Managers need evidence-based information on how to maintain and increase biodiversity in restorations, and the application of ecological theory to restoration has potential to close this information gap. Most relevant, the ‘environmental heterogeneity hypothesis’ predicts that greater variability in resources will enable more species to coexist and promote biodiversity. We initiated a test of this hypothesis in the context of ecological restoration in 1998 by establishing a field experiment that consisted of prairie seeds sown into formerly cultivated soil under non-manipulated, homogeneous conditions or under more spatially heterogeneous conditions created by altering nutrient availability and soil depth. Early results demonstrated a weak effect of manipulated soil heterogeneity on plant diversity due to increasing dominance of one grass species across all soil conditions. Funding from the LTREB program extended the record of plant community dynamics to include 16-20 years following the initial restoration, and a new supply of plant propagules were added during this period to test whether enhanced soil heterogeneity facilitates the establishment of new species and increases plant diversity over the longer-term. We found that after 15 years of restoration and supplemental seed addition, plant diversity in the heterogeneous soil began to increase and diverge from prairie restored under homogeneous soil conditions. Surprisingly, the positive diversity response was primarily attributed to higher cover, diversity, and richness of previously established non-dominant species, and slightly more species where nitrogen was more available, despite negative effects of fertilizer addition on diversity in previous years. Communities establishing in different plots receiving long-term nitrogen addition were dominated by different species, leading to greater variation among communities under heterogeneous relative to homogenous soil conditions. Contrary to how we expected heterogeneity to increase diversity (greater variability in resources for new species to exploit), higher diversity under heterogeneous conditions resulted from the destabilization of formerly grass-dominated communities as a result of long-term nitrogen-enrichment.

This 20-year experiment demonstrates that the ‘environmental heterogeneity hypothesis,’ a widely accepted mechanism used to explain species coexistence in animal communities, may have garnered little experimental support from plant communities because it can take decades for heterogeneity to affect plant diversity. A diversity response to environmental heterogeneity may also be repressed by dominance of perennial clonal plants and enhanced by resources that facilitate dynamic community change (e.g., long-term nutrient enrichment). The long-term community response to nitrogen addition counters the general observation that nutrient enrichment often leads to lower species diversity, particularly in grasslands, and suggests that global change drivers such as elevated nitrogen deposition may impart unpredictable changes in plant community composition over the long-term, posing a real dilemma for restoration practitioners aiming to achieve plant composition and biodiversity goals.
